history.content: Oh dear. The intention is that students will have taken Math 53 before they do anything like 126, 127, to say nothing about 189. You need Math 53 more than you need Math 110, because in reality, 16AB and then certainly 127 will provide you essentially all of the linear algebra that you need.

children.subject:
You don't understand why we require Math 53. That's ok. You are meant to trust the faculty on these matters. There is something called maturity and perspective. Courses are meant to develop this. The challenge with maturity and perspective is that their need is often invisible to people who lack them. 

*Understanding* vector calculus is critically important. Most understand why only after they understand *and* see the struggles of those who do not understand. (Sadly, only one of these is not sufficient. Usually both are required to appreciate why we demand this understanding. When someone has zero of these, the concern is invisible. When they have only one, the concern is often misdiagnosed.)

So, the proper answer to your question is "essentially everywhere."

Hi Professor,
Different anon here. I was looking through the 189 course notes and didn’t see a whole lot of multivar material other than mechanical procedures like differentiation, gradients, and multiple integrals. Perhaps I haven’t looked heard enough, but where exactly does 189 utilize more theoretical aspects of 53? (I haven’t taken it yet either)

Hard choice. Having 16A gives you some optimization thinking, but 16B gives key things like the SVD and PCA, as well as thinking about dynamic systems and control (key for understanding the behavior of machine learning optimization). The default answer is thus to take 127 which would fill the key holes. Without 16A, it would be a clear choice to take 127. At the same time, your understanding of probability is very limited with only 70 and 188, so 126 would be important for building that up. So 126 plus serious self-study of the SVD would also work, given that you have had 16A.

Hi professor Sahai, I'm another anon who is going to be entering his senior year next semester and I am interested in taking 189 by the spring of next semester. I have currently taken: 53, 54, 188, 70, 16A. I am debating on which I should take next semester to maximize my understanding of the 189 course material. Currently, I am gearing more towards taking 126 over 127, but I am curious on what you think would be best for me to take. Thank you!

history.content: OP here: I was able to switch math 110 for math 53. Thank you for your feedback professor!

Hi all,
After this summer, I’ll have finished all CS lower div’s. (Rising sophomore). Looking forward, I want to take CS 189 eventually, but I’m not sure how to fit in Math 53 in my schedule given that I want to take 189 in my fall junior year. As of right now, I’m planning on doing CS170/Math110/Breadth, and then (CS160 or CS162)/EE126/Breadth in my sophomore year. I think it’s too late to enroll in 53 for the coming fall semester, so is it advisable to:
a) self study 53 over the summer
b) take online/community college class 
c) take 189 later and take math 53 in junior year
d) take Math 53 along with ee126
history.subject: When to take Math 53
